sentences.sentence: This was a difficult and delicate( 棘手的 ) job but they managed it in the end.
The little paper bag was very squashy( 易压扁的 ) and sticky( 黏的 ) when they finally got it out,
so that it was more a question of tearing the bag off the toffees( 太妃糖 )  than getting the toffees( 太妃糖 ) out of the bag.
Some grown-ups( 成年人 ) (you know how fussy( 爱挑剔的 ) they can be about that sort of thing) would rather have gone without supper altogether than eaten those toffees( 太妃糖 ).
There were nine of them all told.

It was Digory who had the bright idea of eating four each and planting the ninth; for, as he said, “if the bar off the lamp-post turned into a little light-tree, why shouldn’t this turn into a toffee-tree( 太妃糖树 )?”
So they dibbled( 挖 ) a small hole in the turf( 草皮 ) and buried the piece of toffee( 太妃糖 ).
Then they ate the other pieces, making them last as long as they could.
It was a poor meal, even with all the paper they couldn’t help eating as well.
When Fledge had quite finished his own excellent supper he lay down.
The children came and sat one on each side of him leaning( 倚靠 ) against his warm body,
and when he had spread a wing over each they were really quite snug( 温暖舒适的 ).
As the bright young stars of that new world came out they talked over everything:
how Digory had hoped to get something for his Mother and how, instead of that, he had been sent on this message.
And they repeated to one another all the signs by which they would know the places they were looking for—the blue lake and the hill with a garden on top of it.
The talk was just beginning to slow down as they got sleepy, when suddenly Polly sat up wide awake and said “Hush( 嘘 )!”
Everyone listened as hard as they could.
“Perhaps it was only the wind in the trees,” said Digory presently.
“I’m not so sure,” said Fledge. “Anyway—wait! There it goes again. By Aslan, it is something.”
The horse scrambled( 爬 ) to its feet with a great noise and a great upheaval( 起身 ); the children were already on theirs.
Fledge trotted( 小跑 ) to and fro( 来回地 ), sniffing( 嗅 ) and whinnying( 嘶鸣 ).
The children tiptoed( 踮着脚走 ) this way and that, looking behind every bush and tree.
They kept on thinking they saw things, and there was one time when Polly was perfectly certain she had seen a tall, dark figure gliding( 悄悄移动 ) quickly away in a westerly( 向西方的 ) direction.
But they caught nothing and in the end Fledge lay down again and the children re-snuggled( 再次依偎 ) (if that is the right word) under his wings.
They went to sleep at once.
Fledge stayed awake much longer moving his ears to and fro( 来回地 ) in the darkness and sometimes giving a little shiver( 哆嗦 ) with his skin as if a fly had lighted on him: but in the end he too slept.
“Wake up( 醒醒 ), Digory, wake up( 醒醒 ), Fledge,” came the voice of Polly. “It has turned into a toffee( 太妃糖 ) tree. And it’s the loveliest morning.”
The low early sunshine was streaming through the wood and the grass was gray with dew( 露珠 ) and the cobwebs( 蜘蛛网 ) were like silver.
Just beside them was a little, very dark-wooded tree, about the size of an apple tree.
The leaves were whitish and rather papery( 像纸一样的 ), like the herb( 药草 ) called honesty,
and it was loaded with little brown fruits that looked rather like dates.
“Hurrah( 哈 )!” said Digory. “But I’m going to have a dip first.” He rushed through a flowering thicket( 灌木丛 ) or two down to the river’s edge.
Have you ever bathed in a mountain river that is running in shallow( 小的 ) cataracts( 瀑布 ) over red and blue and yellow stones with the sun on it?
It is as good as the sea: in some ways almost better. Of course, he had to dress again without drying but it was well worth it.
When he came back, Polly went down and had her bathe; at least she said that was what she’d been doing,
but we know she was not much of a swimmer and perhaps it is best not to ask too many questions.
Fledge visited the river too but he only stood in midstream( 河流中心 ), stooping down( 俯身 ) for a long drink of water and then shaking his mane( 鬃毛 ) and neighing( 嘶鸣 ) several times.
Polly and Digory got to work on the toffee-tree( 太妃糖树 ).
The fruit was delicious; not exactly like toffee( 太妃糖 )—softer for one thing, and juicy—but like fruit which reminded one of toffee( 太妃糖 ).
Fledge also made an excellent breakfast;
he tried one of the toffee( 太妃糖 ) fruits and liked it but said he felt more like grass at that hour in the morning.
Then with some difficulty the children got on his back and the second journey began.
It was even better than yesterday, partly because everyone was feeling so fresh,
and partly because the newly risen sun was at their backs and, of course, everything looks nicer when the light is behind you.
It was a wonderful ride. The big snowy mountains rose above them in every direction.
The valleys, far beneath them, were so green, and all the streams which tumbled( 快速流动 ) down from the glaciers( 冰川 ) into the main river were so blue,
that it was like flying over gigantic( 巨大的 ) pieces of jewelry( 珠宝 ).
They would have liked this part of the adventure to go on longer than it did.
But quite soon they were all sniffing( 嗅 ) the air and saying “What is it?” and “Did you smell something?” and “Where’s it coming from?”
For a heavenly smell, warm and golden,
as if from all the most delicious fruits and flowers of the world,
was coming up to them from somewhere ahead.
“It’s coming from that valley with the lake in it,” said Fledge.
“So it is,” said Digory. “And look! There’s a green hill at the far end of the lake. And look how blue the water is.”
“It must be the Place,” said all three.
Fledge came lower and lower in wide circles( 大圈 ).
The icy peaks( 冰峰 ) rose up higher and higher above.
The air came up warmer and sweeter every moment, so sweet that it almost brought the tears to your eyes.
Fledge was now gliding( 滑翔 ) with his wings spread out motionless( 静止的 ) on each side, and his hoofs( 蹄 ) pawing( 用爪子抓 ) for the ground.
The steep( 陡峭的 ) green hill was rushing toward them.
A moment later he alighted( 飞落 ) on its slope( 斜坡 ), a little awkwardly( 笨拙地 ).
The children rolled off( 翻身下马 ), fell without hurting themselves on the warm, fine grass, and stood up panting( 喘息 ) a little.
They were three-quarters of the way up the hill, and set out at once to climb to the top.
(I don’t think Fledge could have managed this without his wings to balance him and to give him the help of a flutter( 扇动 ) now and then.)
All round the very top of the hill ran a high wall of green turf( 草皮 ).
Inside the wall trees were growing. Their branches hung out over the wall;
their leaves showed not only green but also blue and silver when the wind stirred( 吹动 ) them.
When the travelers reached the top they walked nearly all the way round it outside the green wall before they found the gates: high gates of gold, fast shut, facing due east.

article_info.previous: Aslan让Fledge一路护送Digory前往目的地完成使命，Polly也请求一同前往。在大家的祝福和目送下，他们出发去摘苹果。

article_info.share_words: Fledge came lower and lower in wide circles. The icy peaks rose up higher and higher above. The air came up warmer and sweeter every moment, so sweet that it almost brought the tears to your eyes.

question.cn: 关于最后一颗太妃糖，Digory想出了什么好主意？
question.en: What was Digory’s good idea about the last toffee?

options.cn: 他想把太妃糖种在土里。
options.en: He wanted to plant the toffee in the earth.

options.cn: 他想把太妃糖扔在河里。
options.en: He wanted to threw the toffee in the river.
He wanted to give the toffee to Fledge.

analysis: 文中提到：“It was Digory who had the bright idea of eating four each and planting the ninth.”由此可知，Digory所想到的不错的主意是把最后一颗太妃糖种在地上，也许到了第二天它可以长成一颗太妃糖树，因此选A。

question.cn: 最后一颗太妃糖长成了太妃糖树吗？
question.en: Did the last toffee turn into a toffee tree?

analysis: 文中提到：“It has turned into a toffee tree. And it's the loveliest morning.”由此可知，最后一颗太妃糖长成了太妃糖树，因此选A。

question.cn: Fledge在早上更喜欢吃太妃糖还是草？
question.en: Which one did Fledge prefer in the morning, the toffee fruits or grass?

analysis: 文中提到：“He tried one of the toffee fruits and liked it but said he felt more like grass at that hour in the morning.”由此可知，Fledge在早上的时候更喜欢吃草，因此选B。

question.cn: 太妃糖树上的糖果味道怎样？
question.en: How was the fruit from the toffee-tree?

analysis: 文中提到：“Polly and Digory got to work on the toffee-tree. The fruit was delicious; not exactly like toffee-softer for one thing, and juicy-but like fruit which reminded one of toffee.”由此可知，Digory种下的太妃糖长成了太妃糖树，上面的糖果十分的美味，因此选A。

question.cn: 根据Fledge的叙述，气味来自哪里？
question.en: According to Fledge, where was the smell coming from?

options.en: It was coming from the valley.
It was coming from the river.
It was coming from the toffee-tree.

analysis: 文中提到：“For a heavenly smell, warm and golden, as if from all the most delicious fruits and flowers of the world, was coming up to them from somewhere ahead. ‘It’s coming from that valley with the lake in it,’ said Fledge.”由此可见，Fledge认为气味来自山谷里，因此选A。
